Notes: Note: In November, the ministry developed a national emergency response plan for the second wave of COVID-19. The plan has six objectives, including increasing testing capacity and strengthening contact tracing through enhancing community surveillance (this suggests that there is already some, albeit limited, contact tracing). See https://web.archive.org/web/20201130224201/https://www.thelancet.com/action/consumeSharedSessionAction?SERVER=WZ6myaEXBLGG9BXOtoLGog%3D%3D&MAID=Y8sZIZUJ%2Fxh%2B1hNZe9K65A%3D%3D&JSESSIONID=aaa6qrk-F0rxrgd7JOvyx&ORIGIN=915081995&RD=RD

AlJazeera Nov 13: "Bangladesh has extended its closure of schools and educational institutions, which were last open in March, until December 19. The government closed schools and educational institutions on March 17 and has extended the closure several times, most recently until November 15."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122211406/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/11/13/bangladesh-extends-school-shutdown-over-second-covid-19-wave

Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  - Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  - Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  - No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  - Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  - Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  - Residents must work from home.  - Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.  - COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  - Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centres will be closed.  - No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  - Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  - Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Targeted: According to the US Embassy Website in Bangladesh as of Nov 11, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201111005505/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/:   "Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.    It is important to note GoB officials have confirmed that the list of Red zones does not mean the areas are or will be under lockdown restrictions. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  - ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  - Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  - Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."    This information has not changed as of Nov 18, 2020: https://web.archive.org/web/20201122221519/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of December 5th, testing of symptomatic individuals continues.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201213140121/https://www.dhakatribune.com/health/coronavirus/2020/12/02/bangladesh-to-start-antigen-testing-from-december-5

No policy change identified.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201213140430/https://www.who.int/bangladesh/news/detail/06-09-2020-who-strengthens-covid-19-contact-tracing-to-break-the-chain-of-transmission

As part of COVID-19 measures, face masks must be worn at all times when moving in and around Bangladesh. This includes wearing a mask inside all workplaces (public and private), educational institutions, places of worship, hotels, shops, malls, markets, restaurants, hospitals and at social gatherings. You should also wear a mask at home if anyone in your household is displaying COVID-19 symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213135559/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bangladesh/coronavirus

As per this article from 24 Sep, "students of grades IX, X, XI and XII across the country are now back to school."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208090915/https://www.unicef.org/bhutan/stories/and-then-schools-reopened%E2%80%A6

No data found about any mandatory work from home guidelines or closure of businesses currently in place.  This article from 5 Sep indicates offices will continue to work normally from 7 Sep, with provision for certain folks to work from home if needed.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208093035/https://thebhutanese.bt/rcsc-issues-directions-for-civil-servants-to-work-post-lockdown/  The below link indicates "All shops can open but must ensure proper spacing and other COVID-19 etiquettes."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208101528/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/

This article indicates that "The don’ts are not organizing or attending social gatherings."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208093035/https://thebhutanese.bt/rcsc-issues-directions-for-civil-servants-to-work-post-lockdown/
No new data available.
No new data available

There are guidelines for certain categories of people to stay at home - staff who have breastfeeding babies, children below age of one and those who have serious health issues can work from home.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208093035/https://thebhutanese.bt/rcsc-issues-directions-for-civil-servants-to-work-post-lockdown/  The below article also indicates normal activity has resumed but with precautions  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208101528/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/

Some restrictions still exist particularly for movement from high risk to low risk areas  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208101528/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/

Bhutan’s borders are currently closed to foreign nationals, including British citizens. Foreigners, with the exception of citizens from India, Bangladesh and the Maldives nationals, may only enter or depart the country through certain towns such as Phuntsoling, Samdrup Jongkhar and Gelephug (by road) or Paro (by air).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201208100644/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/entry-requirements

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.  Investments in GovTech is allowing Bhutan to reap benefits during COVID-19 including fast disbursement of cash relief funds.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu was launched on 14 April 2020 to provide income support to individuals whose livelihoods were affected because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Between April and September 2020, Nu.1.2 billion was granted to over 33,000 beneficiaries and over 14,000 children.    The Relief Kidu has been extended for three months, from October to December 2020. Individuals who applied for or received Kidu in Phase I and/or Phase II need to re-apply for further assessments. Applications are also open to new applicants who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic.  Who is eligible?  Bhutanese who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic and are currently residing in Bhutan are eligible for the Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu. The displaced group includes those who have been laid off, placed on unpaid leave or on reduced pay from businesses *** as well as self-employed individuals *** who have lost their earnings either partially or completely.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208103817/https://royalkidu.bt/

Business Income tax (BIT) and Corporate Income tax (CIT) filing for the income year 2019 was deferred until June 30, 2020 and tax payments, for tourism and related sectors (hotel, airlines and tour operators) are deferred until December 31, 2020, while for other sectors until September 30, 2020; deferred payment of sales tax and customs duty on essential items (March to June 2020); waiver of payment of rent and other charges (April-December 2020) by tourism-related business entities leasing government properties, deferral of electricity charges payment for industry (till December 2020), free electricity and wi-fi services to hotels serving as quarantine facility (July-September 2020). As of May 25, the government will be refunding the 5 percent sales tax collected on telecom services collected on or after January 16, 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There is a daily update on the government website https://www.gov.bt/ and the Facebook page of the Ministry of Health https://www.facebook.com/MoHBhutan/

Due to surging daily Covid-19 cases, Haryana on 21 November announced closure of schools until 30 November, while Mumbai, Thane, Navi Mumbai and Panvel directed all schools to shut until the end of the year. In Maharashtra, only students of grade 9 and 12 are allowed to go to schools.    https://archive.vn/hRicc

School closures in Haryana were extended to December 10th.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201130191950/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/coronavirus-cases-and-vaccine-updates-live-nov-30/liveblog/79482732.cms?smsid=79495372&%2Fa24gk=    School and college closure in Rajasthan is extended to Dec 31st.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201130192107/https://www.indiatoday.in/education-today/news/story/rajasthan-schools-colleges-to-remain-closed-till-december-31-1745319-2020-11-30
No change in policy found.

No significant change in policy.     New guidance issued Nov 30th which does not significantly change anything.     Essential businesses remain open. Malls, restaurants, theatres, recreation facilities, etc remain open in some areas with restrictions, and closed in other areas. Markets in "containment zones" remain closed until further notice.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130194308/https://www.india.com/news/india/coronavirus-lockdown-latest-news-fresh-guidelines-says-markets-in-containment-zones-to-remain-shut-4233951/
No change in policy found.

India remained in "Unlock 5.0" until Nov 30th.     Public gatherings are banned in "containment zones"  Outside of containment zones, limits on outdoor gatherings have been removed, while indoor gatherings are restricted to 50% capacity.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130194933/https://indianexpress.com/article/india/unlock-5-coronavirus-guidelines-6619158/
No change in policy found.

All districts in the state of Rajasthan will be placed under Section 144 (restrictions on gatherings above 4) from Nov 21.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130195402/https://zeenews.india.com/india/night-curfew-section-144-check-latest-govt-covid-19-restrictions-in-delhi-mumbai-ahmedabad-2325800.html    Additionally, to arrest a second wave in Uttar Pradesh, the Yogi Adityanath government clamped Section 144 in the state capital, as Lucknow now is among six cities with high virus load. Effective from Nov 26th to Dec 1.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201130195532/https://www.businessinsider.in/india/news/section-144-imposed-in-lucknow-kanpur-ghaziabad-greater-noida-meerut-and-agra/articleshow/79423248.cms
Night curfew between 10pm and 6am came into effect from 21 November until further notice in five districts - Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior, Ratlam ad Vidisha.    https://archive.vn/hRicc

In addition to previous night curfews announced Nov 20/21 in Madya Pradesh state in the districts of Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior, Ratlam and Vidisha, additional states have implemented night curfews.     Punjab: Night curfew from 10pm to 5am starting Dec 1.     Rajasthan: Section 144 (prohibiting the gathering of four or more people in a specified area) in all districts. Additional night curfew in 8 districts - Jaipur, Jodhpur, Kota, Bikaner, Udaipur, Ajmer, Alwar and Bhilwara    Gujarat: Night curfew from 9pm to 6am in Rajkot, Surat and Vadodara until further orders    Himachal Pradesh: night curfew from Nov 24 to Dec 15 in 4 districts - Mandi, Shimla, Kullu and Kangra    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130192534/https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/govt-to-hold-talks-with-farmers-on-december-1-as-protests-intensify/story-caNKEKvCJIfmPXrBkChBoI.html      Nov 28: the entire Manipur state instituted a night curfew from 6pm to 4am until Jan 1.  Manipur government has announced a night curfew from 6 pm to 4 am in the state till the end of this year    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130193637/https://www.oneindia.com/india/coronavirus-outbreak-in-view-of-covid-19-manipur-announces-night-curfew-till-december-end-3182539.html

Travel from inside of containment zones is prohibited, but often people do not even know they are in a containment zone.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130200032/https://theprint.in/health/4501-containment-zones-but-little-is-contained-story-of-delhis-faltering-covid-fight/548233/

No change to previous policy.     Currently, India shares bi-lateral travel arrangements with around 22 countries, including the United Kingdom, Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bahrain, Canada, Bhutan, France, Kenya, Iraq, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, Maldives, Qatar, Oman, United Arab Emirates, and the United States. Travel from countries not within these agreements is banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201130210451/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/travel/travel-news/india-ethiopia-air-bubble-arrangement-to-start-indias-travel-bubble-includes-22-countries-now/as79283700.cms  International arrivals must submit a negative PCR test or go to mandatory state-sponsored quarantine. Along with a temperature check upon arrival. https://web.archive.org/web/20201130210135/https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/05112020Guidelinesforinternationalarrivals.pdf
No change.

No change to previous policy.     Despite over 2/3 of MSMEs (Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises) in the country being eligible for the debt restructuring announced by the RBI in August, only about 1% of MSMEs plan to take advantage of this scheme. The offer by the RBI expires Dec 31st, so companies must take advantage before then if they intend to do so.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130210603/https://www.telegraphindia.com/business/few-opt-for-rbis-one-time-debt-restructuring-scheme/cid/1797780

Combing through official twitter accounts and government websites while filling in the rest of this info and I have seen numerous graphics and information about covid, including things like "don't spit in public" "wear a mask".

Since 4 Sept 2020:    In containment zones - anyone symptomatic  In non-containment zones - symptomatic and eligible    https://web.archive.org/web/20201201002756/https://www.icmr.gov.in/pdf/covid/strategy/Testing_Strategy_v6_04092020.pdf

The stated goal of the government is to trace 80% of contacts within 72 hours. https://web.archive.org/web/20201201003307/https://cdnbbsr.s3waas.gov.in/s3850af92f8d9903e7a4e0559a98ecc857/uploads/2020/11/2020112661.pdf

Face masks required in public and in workplaces. State governments are empowered to institute fines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201201003307/https://cdnbbsr.s3waas.gov.in/s3850af92f8d9903e7a4e0559a98ecc857/uploads/2020/11/2020112661.pdf    Deli increased their fine for not wearing a mask from Rs.500 to Rs.2000 on Nov 25th     https://web.archive.org/web/20201201003817/https://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-wearing-mask-mandatory-india-authorities-cracking-delhi-imposed-fine-2000-violation-2858356

On Monday 16th November the government reopened all schools with immediate effect against widespread opposition from parents, teachers and students Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130215543/https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2020/11/30/scho-n30.html

After 24 hours of reopening schools, a number of schools across the country were required to close their doors again. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130215543/https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2020/11/30/scho-n30.html

Required school closures for many levels, especially at a localized levels continues in Sri Lanka.    Notably:  1. Even as the Sri Lankan Govt reopened schools in late November, it permitted schools in certain regions to remain closed until further notice.  - "Education Minister Prof. G.L. Peiris says that schools across the country except the Western Province and selected isolated areas have been reopened for the third term after taking into consideration the concerns, and ensuring that health and safety guidelines are strictly enforced." -- reported on Nov 24, 2020 https://web.archive.org/web/20201213194921/http://www.dailynews.lk/2020/11/24/local/234310/safety-schools-ensured-education-minister-prof-gl-peiris#:~:text=Education%2520Minister%2520Prof.%2520G.L.%2520Peiris%2520says%2520that%2520schools,that%2520health%2520and%2520safety%2520guidelines%2520are%2520strictly%2520enforced.    2. All schools were ordered to be closed completely starting on Nov 7 for three days, and the order was later extended to last till Nov 11, 2020.  sources:  - "The Education Department of the Southern Province said that schools in Galle will close for three days from tomorrow (Nov 7, 2020)". https://web.archive.org/web/20201213194640/https://colombogazette.com/2020/12/06/schools-in-galle-to-close-as-coronavirus-spreads/  - "The closure of  schools in the Galle Education Zone will continue till this Friday (Nov 11 2020), Southern Province Education Ministry Secretary Ranjith Yapa said." https://web.archive.org/web/20201213194634/http://www.dailymirror.lk/breaking_news/Closure-of-schools-in-Galle-extended/108-201422    3. Pre-schools in Sri Lanka to reopen only in 2021  Dec 11, 2020: "Pre-Schools will most likely re-open in January 2021, said State Minister of Women and Child Development, Preschools & Primary Education, School Infrastructure & Education Services – Piyal Nishantha De Silva." - https://web.archive.org/web/20201213195651/https://english.siyathanews.lk/2020/12/11/pre-schools-likely-to-open-next-year-min-piyal-nishantha/

Old one - Some Nepal schools reopen after seven months with measures such as starting 'the classes from Sunday in two shifts following all the healthy protocols'.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022083721/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/covid-19-few-nepal-schools-reopen-after-seven-months/articleshow/78376474.cms

A Spokesperson at the MoEST Dipak Sharma said most schools will resume classes from November 24 for board examination of grade 12. “The government has made all necessary preparations to resume classes in schools following health safety protocols,” he added.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130170416/https://myrepublica.nagariknetwork.com/news/schools-to-reopen-after-chhath-festival/

While schools were reopened across Nepal towards the last week of November - source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213212004/https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/schools-reopen-amid-coronavirus-scare/    Some regions were forced to shut down schools again in early December  source: Nov 30, 2020: "Some schools that resumed classes yesterday after a long time due to coronavirus pandemic were closed today in Shambhunath Municipality, Saptari." https://web.archive.org/web/20201213212045/https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/schools-closed-day-after-they-opened/
No change in policy found.
Nov 23 - Most businesses, stores, restaurants, and hotels have resumed normal operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
No change in policy found.

In line with this decision, people will not be allowed to gather in large numbers at public venues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022085359if_/https://www.deccanherald.com/international/coronavirus-nepal-restricts-mass-gathering-closes-down-public-places-815086.html

Old one - Public transportation, including taxis and buses, and some long distance buses, may operate at  50% occupancy  Masks are required when outdoors, including while on public transport and  taxis    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

The Government of Nepal has authorized local authorities to impose lockdowns within their jurisdictions. Limited lockdowns in Pokhara and many towns in the Terai remain possible.  If you must travel locally, please inquire about local conditions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

The government of Nepal loosened the lockdown in the Kathmandu Valley. However, the government implemented an alternating day even/odd system for the movement of private vehicles based on the last number of the vehicle’s license plate.  Limited long-range public bus transportation  is allowed to operate at 50% capacity and is subject to strict COVID mitigation measures.  The government announced that trekking routes may be opened beginning October 17. Travelers must present negative PCR test results to be eligible for trekking and may be subject to quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Limited commercial flight service has resumed.  Except as described above, foreign citizens are currently prohibited entry into Nepal.  Domestic flights have resumed, including full seating capacity. Each flight will operate under strict COVID mitigation measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Old - Social assistance will be strengthened by providing those most vulnerable with daily food rations, subsidizing utility bills for low-usage customers, extending tax-filing deadlines, and taking measures to partially compensate those in the formal sector for lost wages in the event of job loss. Measure announced April 26. Informal sector workers who have lost their jobs due to the ongoing crisis will be given the opportunity to participate in public-works projects for a subsistence wage or receive 25 percent of local daily wage should they choose not to participate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022092249/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The NRB announced that banks will defer loan repayments due in April and May until mid-July. For working capital loans, banks will extend the repayment schedule of the amount due during the lockdown up to 60 days. Businesses in affected sectors, if they can show the needs, can qualify for additional working capital loans of up to 10 percent of the approved amount of their existing working capital loans, to be repaid within a year at most. The NRB directed banks to apply lower interest rates (up to 2 percentage points) when calculating the interest due for the period of mid-April to mid-July, applicable to borrowers from affected sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022092249/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
good info on public domain - https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Several government designated hospitals offer COVID-19 testing. Individuals must pay the cost testing, which has been mandated by the government at Rs. 2,200.  Reports of private hospitals charging the previous maximum of Rs. 4,400 have been reported.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020230202/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Old - The city has formed five teams for contact tracing for Kathmandu’s 32 wards. Each team should consist of three members—a lab technician, a public health officer and a paramedic—as per the Health Ministry’s guidelines. But there are only two people in a team due to the lack of personnel.  Contact tracing is key, but a lack of human resource is making it ineffective.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022094445/https://kathmandupost.com/health/2020/08/14/contact-tracing-is-key-but-a-lack-of-human-resource-is-making-it-ineffective

The government of Nepal has announced that failure to wear a mask outdoors may result in arrest and a fine.  Specific information about potential penalties has not been published.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201110091942/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Reuters reported on Nov 26: "Pakistan shut its schools and postponed exams on Thursday [26th Nov] to try to curb new coronavirus infections and a rise in the number of people in hospital with COVID-19"; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129195316if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-pakistan-schools-idINKBN28618X    This lines up with reporting from Khaleej Times on Nov 23rd: "Pakistan will close down schools, colleges and universities from November 26 in a bid to contain the spread of Covid-19 pandemic. Shafqat Mahmood, Pakistan’s Education Minister, held a press conference on Monday [Nov 23 2020] to announce the details. He said online classes will continue from November 26 to December 24. The educational institutes will be closed from December 25, 2020 to January 10, 2021 for winter vacations." source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129194756/https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/rest-of-asia/covid-19-pakistan-announces-closure-of-schools-colleges-universities

School closures to continue through Dec 24, 2020:  Reuters reported on Nov 26: "Pakistan shut its schools and postponed exams on Thursday [26th Nov] to try to curb new coronavirus infections and a rise in the number of people in hospital with COVID-19"; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129195316if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-pakistan-schools-idINKBN28618X    This lines up with reporting from Khaleej Times on Nov 23rd: "Pakistan will close down schools, colleges and universities from November 26 in a bid to contain the spread of Covid-19 pandemic. Shafqat Mahmood, Pakistan’s Education Minister, held a press conference on Monday [Nov 23 2020] to announce the details. He said online classes will continue from November 26 to December 24. The educational institutes will be closed from December 25, 2020 to January 10, 2021 for winter vacations." source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129194756/https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/rest-of-asia/covid-19-pakistan-announces-closure-of-schools-colleges-universities

On Nov 24, 2020, Geo News TV provided a useful summary of COVID19 restrictions that show a patchwork of Workplace/educational/gathering restrictions across the country; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201909/https://www.geo.tv/latest/320263-what-are-the-covid-19-restrictions-in-pakistan    These restrictions across different parts of the country suggest governments at the local and state levels imposing targeted restrictions as and when appropriate for workplace restrictions. The strictest of them seem to start on Nov 20 2020, in Pakistan Administered Kashmir where a 15-day lockdown is in place (starting from Nov 20) -- this lockdown has prompted the 3T designation for C2.    In the order of strictness and how early such restrictions seem have come into effect:  1. "A 15-day lockdown has been imposed by the AJK (Azaad Kashmir, aka Pakistan Administered Kashmir) government since November 20. All businesses and offices are closed while the government offices will operate at 50% capacity. Only essential services are allowed with strict implementation of coronavirus SOPs."  2. "Sindh: Markets and business centres are to close by 6pm on weekdays. They can open by 6am, but have to stay closed on weekends, the Sindh home department notified on Monday. All cinemas, shrines, and gyms will be closed. Government and private offices can call in only 50% of staff to work, while the remaining employees are to work from home."  3. "Punjab: Smart lockdowns imposed in 6 cities: Bahawalpur, Bhakkar, Multan, Rawalpindi, Sargodha, and Lahore. All shopping malls, restaurants, offices (private and public) will remain closed in the areas under lockdown. Public and private offices throughout the (Punjab) province are to ensure that 50% of the staff works from home. This will be applicable till January 31, 2021."  4. "The Khyber Pakhtunkhwa government has issued no new coronavirus restrictions this week. Its home department issued SOPs to be followed last week which are still in place. All shopping malls, restaurants, shops, and marriage halls have been directed to shut by 10pm. Pharmacies, medical stores and tandoor shops (and Petrol Pumps and LPG shops) will remain open 24/7."    The details of the work place restrictions, esp. in Punjab and Sindh were also reported by Deccan Herald on Nov 24: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129202234if_/https://www.deccanherald.com/international/world-news-politics/pakistan-provincial-authorities-introduce-new-covid-19-restrictions-national-tally-reaches-379883-919348.html    In General though, on Nov 25 2020 the Pakistan Government (specifically the Prime Minister) has ruled out any broad nation-wide restrictions to contain COVID19: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129210523/https://in.news.yahoo.com/pak-pm-rules-closing-down-175707452.html

Multiple additional "smart lockdowns" are being imposed across the country in Pakistan. Sources:  - Dec 03, thenews.com.pk, "More smart lockdowns for Karachi as coronavirus cases surge":  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191542/https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/753152-more-smart-lockdowns-for-karachi-as-coronavirus-cases-surge  - Dec 01 The Dawn, "70 more areas of Punjab put under smart lockdown":  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191553/https://www.dawn.com/news/1593330    More specifically, the US Embassy in Islamabad (updated on 01 Dec 2020; https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191548/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/) reports the following:     "Some streets, neighborhoods, and commercial zones are currently under lockdown in Pakistan’s major cities.  Areas identified by authorities as COVID-19 “hotspots” could be locked down without advance notice.  Masks are required to be worn when in public, and violators could be fined by law enforcement.  Educational institutions closed November 26 and are expected to reopen in early 2021.  Pakistan issued new restrictions for weddings and large gatherings November 27.  Events must be held outdoors, are limited to 300 people, and cannot last for more than two hours."    According to the same US Embassy Page, Smart Lockdowns in Pakistan are described as:  "There are government “smart” lockdowns (i.e., small localities, such as a building with multiple units, streets, and small neighborhoods, may be sealed to limit the spread of the coronavirus.).  Hours of operation for businesses may be reduced in localities under these targeted lockdowns." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191548/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On Nov 24, 2020, Geo News TV provided a useful summary of COVID19 restrictions that show a patchwork of Workplace/educational/gathering restrictions across the country; source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201909/https://www.geo.tv/latest/320263-what-are-the-covid-19-restrictions-in-pakistan    These restrictions across different parts of the country suggest governments at the local and state levels imposing targeted restrictions as and when appropriate for public events and gatherings. The local government in Pakistan Administered Kashmir, aka Azaad Kashmir, imposed a strict 15-day lockdown starting on Nov 20 2020. As per the Geo New article: "Public gatherings, including weddings, have been banned." Such reporting suggests that public events in targeted/specific regions within the country have be halted/banned.

the US Embassy in Islamabad (updated on 01 Dec 2020; https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191548/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/) reports the following:     "Some streets, neighborhoods, and commercial zones are currently under lockdown in Pakistan’s major cities.  Areas identified by authorities as COVID-19 “hotspots” could be locked down without advance notice.  Masks are required to be worn when in public, and violators could be fined by law enforcement.  Educational institutions closed November 26 and are expected to reopen in early 2021.  Pakistan issued new restrictions for weddings and large gatherings November 27.  Events must be held outdoors, are limited to 300 people, and cannot last for more than two hours."    Multiple additional "smart lockdowns" are being imposed across the country in Pakistan. Sources:  - Dec 03, thenews.com.pk, "More smart lockdowns for Karachi as coronavirus cases surge":  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191542/https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/753152-more-smart-lockdowns-for-karachi-as-coronavirus-cases-surge  - Dec 01 The Dawn, "70 more areas of Punjab put under smart lockdown":  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206191553/https://www.dawn.com/news/1593330

Nov 16, 2020: More stringent restrictions will be implemented on Nov 20th in urban centers.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116020431/http://covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/07November2020_20201106_Additional_Guidelines_on_Marriage_Events_during_COVID_19_4505.pdf

Targeted lockdowns across the country are preventing public events or gatherings.  The local government in Pakistan Administered Kashmir, aka Azaad Kashmir, imposed a strict 15-day lockdown starting on Nov 20 2020. As per the Geo New article: "Public gatherings, including weddings, have been banned."  Similarly, in "Khyber Pakhtunkhwa: All major public gathering have been banned. Legal action will be taken in case of violations."   Such reporting suggests that public events in targeted/specific regions within the country have be halted/banned. source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201909/https://www.geo.tv/latest/320263-what-are-the-covid-19-restrictions-in-pakistan    In general, the Pakistan Government issued guidance on public gatherings such as weddings for crowd sizes as small as 25 people. Broadly such guidance suggests that "No indoor gatherings are permitted, and only outdoor wedding events are allowed, in which number of the guests must not exceed 300 individuals with mandatory arrangements for seating  of each individual at-least 6 feet apart. event timing should be restricted to 2 hours with closure evening timing at 10 PM" Source: https://covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/28November2020_20201127_Additional_Guidelines_for_Marriage_Events_Ceremonies_during_COVID_19_4505.pdf    Additionally, the guidelines provide clear space restrictions for specific crowd sizes. E.g. for a gathering of upto 25 people, there should be at least 900 sq feet of space; for crowds of upto 100 people a minimum of 3600 sq ft. is required.    While the guidance document is date Nov 27th 2020, it also states that "These guidelines will be implemented from 20th November 2020 onwards in urban centers (Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Rawalpindi, Multan, Hyderabad, Gilgit,  Muzaffarabad, Mirpur, Peshawar, Quetta, Gujranwala, Gujrat, Faisalabad, Bahawalpur & Swat)".

Transportation Options:    Are commercial flights operating? [Yes]  Is public transportation operating? [Yes]  According to the Government of Pakistan, individuals using public transportation – trains or buses – should wear facemasks and keep a distance of at least six feet from other individuals.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129214352/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Symptomatic travelers will be required to take a COVID-19 RT-PCR test and its results submitted to the designated Pakistani authorities within 48 hours of arrival. In cases found positive for COVID-19 based on a test upon arrival, travelers may be required to comply with isolation procedures.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129214352/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Nov 16, 2020: "Pakistan has considered to incorporate Ag-RDT in its testing strategy for disease  surveillance and screening."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201116022452/http://covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/05November2020_20201104_TESTING_STRATEGY_INCORPORATING_COVID-19_ANTIGEN_DETECTION_RAPID_DIAGNOSTIC_TESTS_5301.pdf
